page.title: 08ICE HOUSES
page.content: The ice houses which served Forcett and Stanwick Halls still remain. The one at Forcett is sited under an earth mound now covered by trees and shrubs near the lake. Its entrance is via a tunnel at the base of the mound. The one at Stanwick is constructed of natural stone with a slate roof and has its entrance at ground level. The storage chamber is down below ground. Ice taken from the lake in each of these country parks in Winter was used to preserve the fish and game etc. caught or butchered on the estates and stored in these ice houses. Neither is now used, they are simply a part of the heritage of the area as are the remnants of the parklands.
